articles.title: About me
articles.description: I am a human behavioral ecologist, particularly interested in the evolutionary roots of patriarchy as well as the role of men as changemakers and promoters for gender equality and women's empowerment.
articles.contents:
Education
University of California, Santa Barbara | Santa Barbara, CA
Ph.D. in Biological Anthropology | September 2021 - Ongoing
University of California, Santa Barbara | Santa Barbara, CA
M.A. in Biological Anthropology | September 2019 - August 2021
Experience
Jun 2019 Research Assistant to Dr. David Lawson, UCSB –Aug 2019 Mwanza, Tanzania: Full time 40hr/week. Assisted in the training of the Tanzanian research team and led management of field data collection resulting in over 900 completed long form surveys for a study of men’s attitudes to women’s empowerment.
Jan 2019 Primary Investigator, Project School House (PSH) –April 2019 Rio Blanco, Nicaragua: Full time 40hr/week Created original survey materials, trained local research assistant, and personally surveyed 8 rural Nicaraguan communities to evaluate the impact of PSH’s water and sanitation projects in treatment communities as well as collected baseline data to track the impact of interventions in prospective treatment communities.
Jan 2017 Research Assistant to Dr Christopher Von Rueden, University of Richmond. –July 2017 Bolivia: Full and part time 10-40hr/week. Assisted in the preparation for and later implementation of field-based research of the Tsimane people in the Amazon rainforests of Bolivia. Including living with the Tsimane in the Tacuaral field-site, conducting month long survey research, and logging collected data for future analysis.
Publications
Kilgallen JA, Schaffnit SB, Kumogola Y, Galura A, Urassa M. Lawson DW, (in press). Positive correlation between women’s status and intimate partner violence suggests violence backlash in Mwanza, Tanzania. Journal of Interpersonal Violence.
Lawson DW, Schaffnit SB, Kilgallen JA, Kumogola Y, Galura A & Urassa M. (2021). He for She? Variation and exaggeration in men’s support for women’s empowerment in northern Tanzania. Evolutionary Human Sciences. 3: E27.

            Bio
            Joseph Kilgallen is a a third year graduate student in the Integrated Anthropological Sciences wing of the Anthropology department and University of California, Santa Barbara. My research explores the role of men, social learning, and gender norms in perpetuating harmful gender ideologies and limiting efforts towards gender equality and women’s empowerment.

              Bio
              Joseph Kilgallen is a a third year graduate student in the Integrated Anthropological Sciences wing of the Anthropology department and University of California, Santa Barbara. My research explores the role of men, social learning, and gender norms in perpetuating harmful gender ideologies and limiting efforts towards gender equality and women’s empowerment.
